Authors:
Preuttiporn Supaphon, Sita Preedanon, Souwalak
Phongpaichit, Vatcharin Rukachaisirikul
Title:
Antimicrobial and antioxidant properties of crude extracts
from fungal endophytes and their host plant
Keywords:
Endophytic fungi, Nelumbo nucifera, Antimicrobial
activity, Antioxidant activity
Abstract:
This research aims to evaluated the antimicrobial and
antioxidant activities of crude extratcs from endophytic fungi and their
host plant (Nelumbo nucifera). A total of 109 fungal isolates were
obtained from 900 segments. All fungal isolates were identified based on
their morphological characteristics. Thirty-six fungal isolates were
selected by their morphological appearance on potato dextrose agar and
cultured into potato dextrose broth. Fungal endophytes and each part of
plant (leaves, flowers and stamens) were extracted with hexane, ethyl
acetate and methanol. One hundred and eight crude extracts from fungal
endophytes and nine crude extracts from N. nuciferawere determined for
their antimicrobial and antioxidant activities by using a colorimetric
broth microdilution test and DPPH free radical scavenging assay. Cell
ethyl acetate extract (CE) obtained from fungal isolate LF020
(Curvularia geniculata) and FL014 (Curvularia sp.) was the most active
against S. aureus (MIC 8 ug/ml) and MRSA (MIC 4 ug/ml). CE extracts of
fungal isolates FL033 (Fusarium verticillioides.) and FL048 (
Penicillium sclerotiorum) gave the strongest against Cryptococcus
neoformans with MIC 16 ug/ml. On the other hand, plant extracts showed
the lowest antimicrobial activity with MIC 1000 ug/ml. For antioxidant
assay, CE extract from fungal endophytes isolate LF020 had the highest
antioxidant activity with inhibitory concentration (IC50) 0.55mg/ml,
followed by CE extract from stamen with IC50 of 0.59 mg/ml. This study
confirmed that endophytic fungi investigated from N. nucifera is a good
source of novel metabolites for future pharmaceutical applications.
